children.text: Abstract of Hone
Hone is an editor designed to polish your ideas into principles.
$ Problem of Ideas in Our Mind
We are human, generating ideas—instant, rapid, and seemingly emerging from nowhere. It’s not easy to discern where they come from, and we certainly don’t know where they will lead.

Consider time. Imagine we’ve written a book. This book is encapsulated within a specific moment; you can edit it before publication, but not afterward. Even when we create a "digital book," which allows for ongoing edits, readers still engage with it at a particular time. For them, the book feels static during their reading, whether over a few hours or several months, freezing your ideas within that timeframe. In this sense, the book remains fixed, regardless of whether it’s traditional or digital.

However, ideas grow, evolve, and sometimes vanish into thin air. Some may develop into principles that guide your life, while others fade away. The journey of transforming ideas into principles or disappear often goes unrecorded, leaving us without the tools to trace or understand this evolution. In essence, we lack a clear "idea" of how our ideas develop and evolve.
$ The Problem Might Be in How We Perceive a Book

People often start to seek ideas from books to solve problems or find inspiration without clear comprehension about the ideas in the book, On the other hand, writers create books to express their fundamental principles—the core beliefs and values that shape them. These "cores" are like the foundations of a building, that is, the structure of a tangible object. They may not always be perfectly organized, but they are the source from which content flows.

The cores of our minds run deep. They are not easy to access, refine, or bring to the surface. Often, they exist in the subconscious, and because they are unpolished, they may not appear as striking or refined when finally expressed.

As a result, we create various "surfaces" to present these cores instead of revealing the cores themselves. Each reader interacts with the content and may sense the presence of these deeper ideas, but the understanding is never exact. It becomes a chaotic exchange, with writers and readers left in the dark, guessing at each other's true meanings.
$ Solution: Hone your Facets through Articles

The answer becomes clear when we consider the key issues: the passage of time, the evolving "cores" in our minds, and the gap between these cores and the content we create.The journey of an idea evolving into a principle isn’t confined to a single event, an article, or even a book. It occurs through various processes and stages, often intermittently.Imagine mapping out the path an idea takes and the places where developments occur. The locations of these developments—such as events, articles, or books—are familiar to you, yet the path itself is much more abstract. Both the development path and the familiar spaces where ideas evolve coexist in this conceptual framework.In Hone, the foundational content structure is the Article. Here, you can tell stories, extend ideas, and highlight a specific idea with a title, representing a completed thought. We refer to this as a Facet, akin to a section heading. You can polish any Facet by inserting another Facet into it, a process we call "Hone".All Facets are extracted into a list alongside the Articles, emphasizing their equal importance: we Hone Facets through Articles. Over time, this honing sharpens ideas, making them more accurate reflections of your true thoughts.
$ The Simplicity for Hone

Throughout the historical evolution of writing and reading, many tools have been invented—not just physical ones like pencils or typewriters, but also symbolic tools such as notation sheets, bullet lists, and bidirectional linking. These "soft" tools help present, develop, and solidify our thoughts. They work because we adapt to the tools we use, which in turn influence our perception of the world and shape our thinking.

The formats we master become part of us. The mental frameworks provided by these tools integrate into our thought processes. Thus, selecting a tool is significant; it’s akin to choosing a part of ourselves, much like selecting an essential organ.

The challenge lies in tracing the evolution of ideas. This is where Facets come in. To reflect the development of a Facet, honing is recorded. The design is based on Occam's razor, stripping away unnecessary elements and starting with minimal components until a new one needs to be added.

The principle in Hone is consistent: simplicity to the extreme. It offers only two types of text blocks—facets and articles—with articles primarily consisting of facets. Each facet begins with a facet title, highlighted in Hone, which is the only formatting option available. There are no additional features like bold, italic, or underline.

Relationships in Hone are also straightforward: one facet can hone another, and that’s it. The idea is that forming and solidifying thoughts occurs through repeated reflection on similar ideas. Ideas are polished by other ideas until they become core principles of who we are.
We need a tool to facilitate this process. That's why people invented writing tools, and that's why this tool is named Hone.
How to use Hone
$ Two Formats in Hone: Facet and Article

Facets begin with a facet title, a line that starts with the $ symbol. You can type $ yourself or use /create to insert it. The title turns green when it is updated and yellow when it is a draft. Everything until the next facet title belongs to that facet. Articles are made of multiple facets, with optional intro text before the first facet.
The simplicity is deliberate: a small structure keeps ideas clear and easy to revisit.
$ How to update a facet
Place the caret inside a facet. Type / at the start of a line and choose /update to save it to the library. Updated facets turn green, and the Facets tab shows the latest updated time.
$ How to Hone a Facet
Honing inserts another facet into the one you are editing. Type / at the start of a line and choose /hone. You will see a list of facets with similarity scores, then pick one to insert.
Inserted facets are wrapped with a header and footer: --- honed-from: <id> | <title> | <timestamp> --- and --- end honed-from ---.
$ The Record of Honing Facets

Each hone action is recorded. In the Facets tab you can browse all facets, see their updated time, and review a Honed from list with similarity and timestamp for each source facet. The list is ordered by most recently updated.
$ Storage and Saving Mechanism
All data in Hone is stored locally in your browser's LocalStorage. There is no cloud storage and no account required. Saving is automatic; edits are saved within about a second.
Use Import/Export in the footer to back up or move your data.
$ Deletion of an Article
To delete an article, remove all of its content; empty articles are automatically removed from storage.
$ Create an Article to Start Using Hone

Click "Create Article" in the top-right of the home page. Start a facet by typing $ at the beginning of a line or by using /create. Use /update to save the facet to the library, and /hone to insert another facet.
